title: Harvard Slips on a Global Ranking List, as Chinese Schools Surge Ahead
summary: Harvard still dominates, though it fell to No. 3 on a list measuring academic output. Other American universities are falling farther behind their global peers.

title: Federal Agent Shoots and Injures Man in Minneapolis, and F.B.I. Searches Reporter’s Home
summary: Plus, a space station evacuation.

title: Federal Agent Shoots Man in Minneapolis, Prompting Tense Protests
summary: The agent shot a Venezuelan man who was resisting arrest, an official said. Protesters and law enforcement officers clashed for hours, as city officials urged people to go home.

title: One State, Two Very Different Views of Minneapolis
summary: Pull up a stool at Ye Olde Pickle Factory and listen to a story about America’s urban-rural divide.

title: Judge to Weigh Next Steps in Student Activist Deportations Case
summary: The hearing on Thursday followed up on the court’s sweeping finding in September that noncitizen students had the same free speech rights as citizens.

title: Woman Killed by ICE Agent Seemed at Fault, N.Y. Republican Says
summary: Bruce Blakeman, the likely Republican candidate for governor, said the killing of Renee Good was just one point of disagreement between him and Gov. Kathy Hochul, a Democrat.

title: Trump Vows to Make Venezuela Rich. It Will Take More Than U.S. Cash.
summary: History suggests that the price of oil and a wider distribution of wealth are as important as foreign investment.

title: Nobel Committee Takes Heat at Home as Machado Courts Trump in D.C.
summary: The Venezuelan opposition leader’s attempts to share her award with the U.S. president have shaken some Norwegians’ faith in their signature soft-power tool.

title: Cyberattack in Venezuela Demonstrated Precision of U.S. Capabilities
summary: Senators are expected to ask Lt. Gen. Joshua M. Rudd, President Trump’s nominee to lead the U.S. Cyber Command, about the mission in Caracas.

title: The U.S. Is Pressing Mexico to Allow U.S. Forces to Fight Cartels
summary: The United States is escalating pressure on the Mexican government to permit the U.S. military to target fentanyl labs, according to American officials.

title: Trump Says Iran Is Stopping Its Killings of Protesters as U.S. Moves Troops
summary: Nonessential personnel were moved from Al Udeid Air Base in Qatar, an American site that could be a target of Iran if President Trump ordered an attack on the country.

title: Trump’s Gulf Allies Do Not Want Him to Bomb Iran
summary: While several of the Gulf Arab countries harbor little love for Iran, they worry that the consequences of rising tensions could blow back on them.

title: Russia Knocks Out the Heat in Ukraine
summary: The Kremlin has tried for years to freeze Ukraine into submission. This winter, its attacks have been the most devastating ever.

title: 3 More Lawmakers in Video Say Federal Prosecutors Are Investigating Them
summary: The lawmakers, all Democrats who urged military service members not to follow illegal orders, said prosecutors had contacted them. But it is unclear what crime they might have committed.

title: Leading Prediction Firms Share a Commonality: Donald Trump Jr.
summary: Traders in companies with ties to the president’s eldest son can bet on the outcome of events the president affects.

title: Congress Is Spurning Many of Trump’s Proposed Spending Cuts
summary: Months after the partisan clash that led to the longest shutdown in history, lawmakers have agreed on spending bills that look far different from what the president wanted.

title: After Danish and U.S. Officials Meet on Greenland, Trump Remains Unmoved
summary: Denmark’s foreign minister left the White House complex saying that his country had a “fundamental disagreement” with President Trump, as several NATO countries sent troops to Greenland.

title: Food Prices Keep Climbing, Rattling Consumers and Trump
summary: Weather, supply, tariffs, labor and changing consumer habits continue to drive up the cost of groceries. President Trump falsely claims prices are falling.

title: Trump Signs Bill Allowing Schools to Serve Whole Milk Again
summary: The law, which was approved unanimously by Congress late last year, also gives schools more flexibility in serving nondairy milks.

title: Is Whole Milk Healthier for Kids?
summary: A new law will allow full-fat and 2 percent milk to be served in schools. Here’s what to know.

title: Why Are We Still So Afraid of Using the Grumpy Old Period?
summary: Exclamation marks, ellipses and ‘haha’ can’t fix our growing inability to communicate.

title: The Gaudy, Nasty Fictions of Donald J. Trump
summary: This is neither law nor order, and the consequences can be deadly.

title: Democrats Will Lose in 2028 Unless They Change Course Now
summary: Despite the successes of 2025, the party still needs a radical shake up.

title: Greenland’s Future
summary: We examine the debate over the Arctic island and what residents are saying.

title: Colbert Jokes That Trump Has Found ‘a New National Bird’
summary: “You got to hand it to that auto worker for getting under Trump’s skin,” Stephen Colbert said after the president appeared to flip off a heckling worker at a Ford plant.

title: A Look At Antarctica From Above
summary: After nearly two weeks at sea without being able to launch his drone, New York Times photographer Chang W. Lee finally captures Antarctica from the air.

title: How One Company, Neptune Flood, Is Pushing a Private Takeover of Flood Insurance
summary: For half a century, a federal program has covered most at-risk properties. Now, a private company is pitching a plan to shrink the government’s role.

title: Au Pair Testifies of Lurid Plot in Virginia Double-Murder Trial
summary: Juliana Peres Magalhães wrapped up testimony on Wednesday in the case against Brendan Banfield, her former lover, who is accused of killing his wife and another man.

title: Many Mayors Have Tried to Help Small Businesses. It’s Mamdani’s Turn.
summary: Small business advocates in New York are excited that Mayor Zohran Mamdani is tackling the issue of excessive fees and fines, but they’ve heard similar promises before.
